INFO 2950: 

Intro to Data Science


Lecture 16

2023-10-23

1

Agenda

1.
Binomial distributions

2.
Explanations with distributions

a.
Tennis example

b.
Hypothesis testing

2

The Binomial Distribution

Counting the number of 
positive events X out of total 
events N 
where each event has 
probability 
p
 to be 
positive is the pattern for a binomial distribution

We'll start by defining the 
probability
 of a sequence, 
then show how to relate this to a count

3

Example: opinion poll, single 
yes/no question

●
Event space
: 0 ... N yeses


●
Parameters
: N, p


●
Probability function
: from the 
Binomial 
distribution

5

Counting i.i.d. events is the basis for 
binomial distribution

6

https://de.maplesoft.com/support/help/maple/view.aspx?path=MathApps/NormalApproximationOfBinomialDistribution

What about bootstrap?

●
We can always use bootstrap samples, but there are 
certain processes that occur frequently where we can 
define properties of that process using a 
probability 
distribution
.


●
Why might we prefer using a probability distribution 
over bootstrapping?  It’s
 
faster
 
and easier than 
bootstrapping, and there’s a lot of 
theory
 behind it to 
describe important data qualities.

7

Motivation: Binomial distribution statistics

8

To understand yes/no 
probability 
functions...

●
We need to understand distributions!

○
We’ll build up our understanding starting 
from histograms


●

How do you know if you can use 
a 
binomial distribution?

30

1.
Each trial has only 2 possible outcomes: 
“success” (1) or “failure” (0)


2.
You conduct each “trial” exactly the same way 
for a fixed number of times 
n


3.
The probability of success 
p
 is the same for 
each trial


4.
Trials are independent

How do you know if you can use 
a 
binomial distribution?

31

1.
Each trial has only 2 possible outcomes: 
“success” (1) or “failure” (0)


2.
You conduct each “trial” exactly the same way 
for a fixed number of times 
n


3.
The probability of success 
p
 is the same for 
each trial


4.
Trials are independent

“Bernoulli trial”

How do you know if you can use 
a 
binomial distribution?

32

1.
Each trial has only 2 possible outcomes: 
“success” (1) or “failure” (0)


2.
You conduct each “trial” exactly the same way 
for a fixed number of times 
n


3.
The probability of success 
p
 is the same for 
each trial


4.
Trials are independent

“repeated Bernoulli 
trials”: conditions are 
the same for each 
trial (identically 
distributed)

How do you know if you can use 
a 
binomial distribution?

33

1.
Each trial has only 2 possible outcomes: 
“success” (1) or “failure” (0)


2.
You conduct each “trial” exactly the same way 
for a fixed number of times 
n


3.
The probability of success 
p
 is the same for 
each trial


4.
Trials are independent

the result of one trial 
doesn’t affect the 
result of another trial

Notation

34

X = number of successes


If our 4 conditions are met, X is a 
“binomial 
random variable”
 


We can talk about the probability P(X=k) 
where k = a specific number of outcomes 
we’re interested in

Notation

35

X = number of successes


If our 4 conditions are met, X is a 
“binomial 
random variable”
 


We can talk about the probability P(X=k) 
where k = a specific number of outcomes 
we’re interested in


E.g., for 10 coin flips 
with a fair coin, define 
P(X=5) as the 
probability that you get 
5 heads

Notation

36

X = number of successes


If our 4 conditions are met, X is a 
“binomial 
random variable”
 


We can talk about the probability P(X=k) 
where k = a specific number of outcomes 
we’re interested in


E.g., for 10 coin flips 
with a fair coin, does 
P(X=11) make sense?

Notation

37

X = number of successes


If our 4 conditions are met, X is a 
“binomial 
random variable”
 


We can talk about the probability P(X=k) 
where k = a specific number of outcomes 
we’re interested in


E.g., for 10 coin flips 
with a fair coin, does 
P(X=11) make sense? 
Not really, but it’ll be 0.

Is X a binomial random variable? 

38

Toss a weighted coin 100 times. 
 

X is the number of heads.

Probability of heads is 70% each time.

https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat414/lesson/10/10.2

Yes, assuming no magic involved

Can you use a binomial distribution?

Sample students until you’ve found one 
who likes cats.


X = number of students sampled.



Probability of a student liking cats is 28%.

n
 defined!

Can you use a binomial distribution?

42

Pumpkin quality is either “rotten” or 
“acceptable,” with 20% of pumpkins 
being rotten.


Inspect the quality of 15 pumpkins by 
randomly sampling 5 pumpkins without 
replacement.


X = number of acceptable pumpkins.

https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat414/lesson/10/10.2
 

X = 
number of successes

1.
Each trial has only 2 possible 
outcomes: “success” (1) or 
“failure” (0)


2.
You conduct each “trial” 
exactly the same way for a 
fixed number of times n


3.
The probability of success p 
is the same for each trial


4.
Trials are independent

琀
琀

Can you use a binomial distribution?

43

Pumpkin quality is either “rotten” or 
“acceptable,” with 20% of pumpkins 
being rotten.


Inspect the quality of 15 pumpkins by 
randomly sampling 5 pumpkins 
without
 
replacement.


X = number of acceptable pumpkins.

https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat414/lesson/10/10.2
 

X = 
number of successes

1.
Each trial has only 2 possible 
outcomes: “success” (1) or 
“failure” (0)


2.
You conduct each “trial” 
exactly the same way for a 
fixed number of times n


3.
The probability of success p 
is the same for each trial


4.
Trials are independent

No!  First trial: p = 12/15.  If a rotten pumpkin is selected, the second trial’s 
p = 12/14, but if an acceptable pumpkin is selected, p = 11/14.

Always check whether you can 
use a binomial distribution!

44

1.

for a fixed number of times 
n

p
 is the same for 
each trial


4.
Trials are independent

Counting i.i.d. events

p
=P(1), 
N = 
the total 
number of trials, and

http://bcs.whfreeman.com/webpub/statistics/spa3e/analyze_data/prob.html
 

We can calculate the probability among multiple success counts

... by summing each of the red bars

Pr = 0.2461

Pr = 0.2051

60

http://bcs.whfreeman.com/webpub/statistics/spa3e/analyze_data/prob.html
 

We can calculate the probability among multiple success counts

... by summing each of the red bars

Pr = 0.2461

Pr = 0.2051

P(5 ≤ X ≤ 6) = P(X = 5) + P(X = 6)



     = 0.2461 + 0.2051



     = 0.4512

61

http://bcs.whfreeman.com/webpub/statistics/spa3e/analyze_data/prob.html

62

http://bcs.whfreeman.com/webpub/statistics/spa3e/analyze_data/prob.html
 

P(X ≥ 5)

http://bcs.whfreeman.com/webpub/statistics/spa3e/analyze_data/prob.html
 

This has a special name: the 
cumulative
 binomial probability

64

http://bcs.whfreeman.com/webpub/statistics/spa3e/analyze_data/prob.html
 

This is equivalent to calculating the probability between 5 and 10 
successes inclusive  (since our max # coin flips is 10)

65

http://bcs.whfreeman.com/webpub/statistics/spa3e/analyze_data/prob.html
 

This is equivalent to calculating the probability between 5 and 10 
successes inclusive  (since our max # coin flips is 10)

P(X ≥ 5) = P(X=5) + P(X=6) + ... + P(X=n)

66

http://bcs.whfreeman.com/webpub/statistics/spa3e/analyze_data/prob.html
 

Confidence check: this probability is > the 0.4512 probability of the 
5-success and 6-success red bars, which makes sense

Entire distribution is “right-skewed”


It’s hard to get a lot of successes if the 
chance of each success is very small!

Why does this matter?

●
We can talk about the probability with which 
we think certain sequences will happen


●
We can compare different probabilities to 
each other

84

Uses of distributions

●
They allow us to make precise statements about 
how uncertain we are


●
They help us compare explanations

○
Of two explanations, which is more likely?

○
Does this set of observations need an 
explanation, or is it just random?

○
What is the single most likely explanation?

it was just the 
wind. old 
houses make 
strange noises. 
go back to sleep.

it's a ghost! don't 
look under the bed!!!

Boring
 
hypothesis

Spooky
 
hypothesis

What was that noise?

Uses of distributions

●
Allow us to easily run 
hypothesis tests


○
Use the distribution to tell us which is 
likelier: the null (boring) hypothesis or the 
alternative (spooky) hypothesis


○
Can do one-sided or two-sided hypothesis 
tests, depending on the situation


90

Tennis refresher

Each tennis player has some number of 
serves (S)
 per game

A serve may result in several outcomes including an 
ace (A)
, 
where the receiver does not get their racquet on the ball and 
the server gets a point.

What is the probability that a player will serve an ace in any 
given serve?

91

Many, many factors, we will 
ignore (almost) all of them!

Tennis refresher

Each tennis player has some number of 
serves (S)
 per game

A serve may result in several outcomes including an 
ace (A)
, 
where the receiver does not get their racquet on the ball and 
the server gets a point.

What is the probability that a player will serve an ace in any 
given serve?

93

Factor: being an extremely 
good tennis player

Competing explanations

1.
Serena Williams is equally as good as any other tennis 
player, someone has to serve the most aces each year


2.
Serena Williams is much better than other professional 
tennis players

94

https://australiansportscamps.com.au/blog/techniques-and-tactics-that-serena-williams-uses/

Competing explanations

1.
Serena Williams is equally as good as any other tennis 
player, someone has to serve the most aces each year

Women’s Tennis Association (WTA) 2012: 


~
196,400 Serves (S) 
→
 11,655 Aces (A)

Williams 2012 (record # year): 


~
2,320 Serves (S) 
→
 484 Aces (A)

2.
Serena Williams is much better than other professional 
tennis players

The 68/95/99.7 rule

If a distribution is approximately normal:

●
68% within ONE standard deviation

●
95% within TWO standard deviations

●
99.7% within THREE standard deviations

●
Almost nothing outside 3 sd


115

The 68/95/99.7 rule

If a distribution is approximately normal:

●
68% within ONE standard deviation

●
95% within TWO standard deviations

●
99.7% within THREE standard deviations

●
Almost nothing outside 3 sd

When N is large and p is not close to 0 or 1, binomial is 
approximately normal

A hypothesis test gets us from an 
observed number to some sort of 
standardized “spooky score”




Serena 
Williams

What do we need for a 
hypothesis test?

135

●
Null (boring) hypothesis H
0

●
Alternative (spooky) hypothesis H
1

●
Plot where your value is relative to the 
distribution

●
Decide whether you 
reject the null
 

(“Tradition” says: at alpha level 5%, do you have a z-score 
greater than [
the z-score reference from z-table, 1.645
]? If yes, 
reject the null – it’s spooky)


Serena 
Williams

What do we need for a 
hypothesis test?

136

Alpha: the probability of rejecting the null 
hypothesis when it was in fact true


(“Tradition” says: at 
alpha
 level 5%, do you have a z-score 
greater than [
the z-score reference from z-table, 1.645
]? If yes, 
reject the null – it’s spooky)


Serena 
Williams

What do we need for a 
hypothesis test?

137

Alpha
: the probability of rejecting the null 
hypothesis when it was in fact true (also known 
as probability of Type I Error or 
False Positive
!)


(“Tradition” says: at 
alpha
 level 5%, do you have a z-score 
greater than [
the z-score reference from z-table, 1.645
]? If yes, 
reject the null – it’s spooky)


Serena 
Williams

What do we need for a 
hypothesis test?

138

If your p-value is greater than alpha, you cannot 
reject the null hypothesis.  (
Boring case!
)

If your p-value is less than alpha, you can reject 
the null hypothesis. (
Spooky case!
)

Serena 
Williams

What is a p-value?

139

●
The probability that something 
occurred, given the null hypothesis 
is true

○
Lower p-value 
→
 spookier 
→
 more 
“statistical significance” of your 
observation

○
The cumulative distribution function 
(under the null hypothesis) at the 
observed x-value

https://www.simplypsychology.org/p-value.html

Is 5% a magic number?

140

●
Would someone at the black vertical line 
here (
p=0.04
) necessarily be considered 
“spooky”?

○
Not necessarily!


●
5% is a useful benchmark but not a hard 
and fast rule

Estimating the reproducibility of psychological science 
(Open Science Collaboration)

https://www.science.org/doi/full/10.1126/science.aac4716

P-hacking

"Perhaps the worst fallacy is the kind of self-deception for which 
psychologist Uri Simonsohn of the University of Pennsylvania and his 
colleagues have popularized the term 
P
-hacking; it is also known as 
data-dredging, snooping, fishing, significance-chasing and
 
double-dipping. 'P-hacking,'
 says Simonsohn, 
'is trying multiple things
 
until you get the desired result'
 — even unconsciously. It may be the first 
statistical term to rate a definition in the online 
Urban Dictionary
, where 
the usage examples are telling: 'That finding seems to have been 
obtained through 
p
-hacking, the authors dropped one of the conditions 
so that the overall 
p
-value would be less than .05,' and 'She is a 
p
-hacker, she always monitors data while it is being collected.'"

-
Regina Nuzzo

152

https://www.nature.com/articles/506150a

P-hacking’s family

Preregistering the study and documenting a final analysis plan avoids 
several pitfalls associated with the recent replication crisis: 
questionable
 
research practices
 (
John et al., 2012
), 
HARKing
 -- hypothesizing after 
results are known (
Kerr, 1998
), 
gardens of forking paths
 (
Gelman and 
Loken, 2014
), and 
p-hacking
 (
Schuemie et al., 2018
).

-
Mike Powell, Allison Koenecke, et al.

153

https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fphar.2021.700776/full#B65

Only spooky results get published

“For any given research area, one cannot tell 
how many studies have been conducted but 
never reported. The extreme view of the 
"file
 
drawer problem"
 is that journals are filled with 
the 5% of the studies that show Type I errors, 
while the file drawers are filled with the 95% of 
the studies that show nonsignificant results.”

-
Robert Rosenthal

154

https://psycnet.apa.org/record/1979-27602-001
 

https://www.walmart.com/ip/Filing-Cabinet-18-W-3
-Drawer-Organizer-File-Black/20470615

What happens when publishing p < 0.05

One implication is that 
about 1 in 20 "significant" findings is likely to
 
be a fluke
. In practice, the number may be far larger, as scientists 
often don't publish papers that fail to find a significant result. So, 
published research is likely to overrepresent the flukey 5 percent. 
And if the flukey 5 percent are especially interesting, perhaps 
because of their novel and unexpected findings, then 
media
 
coverage may exaggerate this overrepresentation even further
.

-
Tania Lombrozo

155

https://www.npr.org/sections/13.7/2013/02/25/172779912/science-a-relationship-you-may-not-understand

Preregister hypotheses (Phase 3)

●
We can avoid p-hacking by being open about our science!


●
Open access to data (if legal and ethical): GitHub, OSF


●
Preregistering analyses and hypotheses (e.g. AsPredicted)

○
Pre-establish what analysis you’ll run, how many times you’ll run 
it, etc. so we know you aren’t cherry picking results

○
Always report the findings from your preregistered analyses, 
even if they’re null results!

156
